source: Nocedal, J. and Wright, S. J. (2006). Numerical Optimization (2nd ed.). Springer.
description: Following Algorithm 7.4 on page 178, the complexity analysis shows that L-BFGS achieves O(md) time complexity per iteration using the two-loop recursion scheme.

complexityStatements.explanation: Storage of m vector pairs {s_i, y_i}, each of dimension d

complexityStatements.breakdown: 4md scalar multiplications in the two loops + d for initial Hessian approximation
complexityStatements.explanation: Forward loop: m iterations × d operations; Backward loop: m iterations × d operations

complexityStatements.notes: where m is number of stored pairs, n is dimension (our notation: m→M, n→d)

keyInsight: The two-loop recursion in Algorithm 7.4 avoids the O(d²) cost of explicitly forming and multiplying with the Hessian approximation. Instead, it computes the product H_k * ∇f_k using O(md) operations by performing two passes through the m stored vector pairs.
quotedText: Without considering the multiplication H_k^0 q, the two-loop recursion scheme requires 4mn multiplications; if H_k^0 is diagonal, then n additional multiplications are needed.
